title: What is the possible etymology of the name "Saturno" and its connection with the Sanskrit name for the Golden Age?
first_phrase: In this text, the author discusses the etymology of the name of the god Saturn in relation to the planet and its ancient significance. The author examines various modern etymologies and suggests another that takes into account the similarity with the Etruscan name for the corresponding deity, Satre, and the Anglo-Saxon name for the planet, Saeter. The author highlights the importance of Saturn in ancient times as the first planet, preceding Jupiter, and its association with the oldest reigning kingdom. The text also references the naming of the days of the week after the planets and their deities, with Saturday being named after Saturn.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the comparison between Anglo-Saxon and ancient Roman deities reveals interesting linguistic and cultural connections that show how different cultures have perceived and named the days of the week based on their beliefs and traditions. These similarities and differences shed light on the complex history and evolution of Western civilization, highlighting the enduring influence of classical mythology and ancient religions on modern societies.
